This supersedes IRM 8.26.8 dated January 15,

Compliance Assurance Process - Fast Track Settlement 8.26.8 page
The IRS announced the CAP pilot in Announcement 2005-87, 2005-50 I.R.B.
The IRS expects CAP to improve issue resolution by working with the taxpayer to determine the tax treatment of items and transactions prior to filing.

Specific corporations are assigned an Account Coordinator (AC), who works with the taxpayer and coordinates additional IRS resources as needed, to review items, events and material tax transactions in a poraneous manner to resolve issues prior to filing. The Account Coordinator and the taxpayer identify and resolve material issues during the tax year rather than several years after a return is filed. When agreement on the proper tax treatment is reached, the Taxpayer receives an acceptance letter from the IRS, minimizing the need for post
filing review of specific items, transactions or issues.

) CAP is comprised of several key components: a. Collaborative relationship between the taxpayer and the AC, the IRS of contact to identify and resolve issues during the year. b. Comprehensive and contemporaneous disclosure environment to issues. c. Issue-driven approach focusing on significant items and events, and material tax transactions. Timely identification, evaluation and resolution issues prior to filing the tax return. d. Determination of acceptance prior to filing. e) Joint post-filing review of return. (
) Issues that arise in the CAP process are resolved by the CAP Team and the taxpayer using Issue Resolution Agreements (IRA). See (
) Fast Track Settlement is available as an Alternative Dispute Resolution program during CAP on an issue by issue basis. See Rev. Proc.
C.B.

, for the Fast Track Settlement procedures. a. Fast Track Settlement is designed to help Large Business and Interna- tional (LB&I) taxpayers expeditiously resolve disputes during an examination while their case is still in LB&I jurisdiction. Fast Track ment brings Appeals resources to the audit site to resolve the disputed treatment of identified transactions. b. Rev. Proc.

provides that the FTS Appeals Official, serving as a neutral participant in the FTS process, assists LB&I and the taxpayer to understand the nature of the dispute and to reach a mutually resolution consistent with applicable law. c. In the FTS process, a specially trained Appeals Official facilitates the Track settlement discussions between the taxpayer and LB&I, to reach and execute a settlement with which both agree. d. a. Collaborative relationship between the taxpayer and the AC, the IRS point of contact to identify and resolve issues during the year. b. Comprehensive and contemporaneous disclosure environment to identify issues. c. Issue

driven approach focusing on significant items and events, and material tax transactions. Timely identification, evaluation and resolution of issues prior to filing the tax return. d. Determination of acceptance prior to filing. e) Joint post
filing review of return.
Fast Track Settlement is available as an Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR) program during CAP on an issue by issue basis. See Rev. Proc.
C.B.
, for the Fast Track Settlement procedures.

a. Fast Track Settlement is designed to help Large Business and Interna- tional (LB&I) taxpayers expeditiously resolve disputes during an examination while their case is still in LB&I jurisdiction. Fast Track Settle- ment brings Appeals resources to the audit site to resolve the disputed tax treatment of identified transactions. b. Rev. Proc.

provides that the FTS Appeals Official, serving as a neutral participant in the FTS process, assists LB&I and the taxpayer to understand the nature of the dispute and to reach a mutually satisfactory resolution consistent with applicable law. c. In the FTS process, a specially trained Appeals Official facilitates the Fast Track settlement discussions between the taxpayer and LB&I, to reach and execute a settlement with which both agree. d. The prohibition against ex parte communications between Appeals employees and other Service employees provided by section

does not apply to the communications when facilitating an agreement between the taxpayer and LB&I during Fast Track Settlement because the Appeals employees are not acting in their traditional Appeals settlement role. e. The Team Manager starts the process by submitting the Application for Fast Track Settlement to the LB&I and Appeals Fast Track Settlement Program Managers. f. In addition to the LS feature code, Appeals uses the CP feature code on Appeals Centralized Database System (ACDS ) for CAP cases requesting Fast Track Settlement. The feature codes are selected from a drop down menu on ACDS. Appeals Officers (AOs ) or Appeals Team Case Leaders (ATCLs ) add the feature code to the case on ACDS, either by adding it themselves through the update function in CARATS or by requesting Account and Processing Support (APS ) add the feature code. The code field in ACDS is critical for Appeals data accuracy on all cases. g. If the parties reach agreement, Form
, Closing Agreement on Final termination Covering Specific Matters, is executed to finalize the resolution. (
) If the Fast Track Settlement Program is used in a CAP case, the Account Co- ordinator (AC) should follow the procedures outlined in Rev. Proc.

a. The AC prepares the application package and forwards it to the Team Manager for approval. The Team Manager reviews, approves, signs the application and obtains the taxpayer’s signature and forwards it to the LB&I and Appeals Fast Track Settlement Program Managers. b. The AC forwards the issue positions for both parties to Appeals for eration, prior to the opening conference and arranges any meetings. The Team Manager and appropriate team personnel, including specialists, managers and Technical Advisors from LB&I participate in the Fast Track Settlement process with taxpayers, which includes attending meetings, discussions, and providing necessary information to achieve a sive understanding of the issue. c. If necessary, the appropriate Territory Manager and Director, Field Opera- tions - LB&I, participates in the Fast Track Settlement process. d. If an issue is resolved during Fast Track Settlement, the agreed resolution is incorporated into the applicable closing agreement. e. Fully developed but unagreed issues not resolved using Fast Track ment during pre-filing are incorporated into a
-day letter once the return is filed and the case is forwarded through the traditional Appeals process. (
) Binding arbitration is not an option that is available in CAP. (

) If Fast Track Settlement does not occur prior to return filing, taxpayers have the option of electing to use Fast Track Settlement during the post-filing nation process. Once the taxpayer elects Fast Track Settlement in CAP, the taxpayer retains all of its otherwise available appeal rights; however, FTS number can not be used for the same issue. An exception is a change in facts and circumstances that the parties subsequently agree merits the use of Fast Track Settlement.

If the Fast Track Settlement Program is used in a CAP case, the Account Co- ordinator (AC) should follow the procedures outlined in Rev. Proc. 2003-40.

Binding arbitration is not an option that is available in CAP. If Fast Track Settlement does not occur prior to return filing, taxpayers have the option of electing to use Fast Track Settlement during the post

nation process. Once the taxpayer elects Fast Track Settlement in CAP, the taxpayer retains all of its otherwise available appeal rights; however, FTS number can not be used for the same issue. An exception is a change in facts and circumstances that the parties subsequently agree merits the use of Fast Track Settlement.

) Upon completion of the Fast Track Settlement in a CAP case, the FTS Official prepares a Fast Track Settlement Session Report, to be signed by parties. of (
) If an issue is settled during Fast Track Settlement, the agreed settlement is documented in Form
, Fast Track Session Report, and the applicable Form
, Closing Agreement on Final Determination Covering Specific Matters, is prepared by Appeals. The FTS Appeals Official also prepares a brief Appeals Case Memorandum (ACM). (

) If an issue is resolved using LB&I resolution authority during Fast Track ment, the original IRA is attached to the final signed Fast Track Settlement Session Report. The FTS Appeals Official does not prepare an Appeals Memorandum. If the parties desire, the agreed resolution is incorporated the applicable Form
prepared by the AC and executed by the LB&I official upon completion of CAP. Appeals assists the parties in drafting Form

) Where a Joint Committee report is required for a CAP case, Appeals execution of the closing agreement until LB&I completes the Joint procedures. LB&I is responsible for preparing the Joint Committee report. When Appeals settlement authority is utilized on a Joint Committee case, Appeals Official involved in the settlement is available to respond to from the Joint Committee regarding the settlement. (
) Appeals follows the established closing procedures for Fast Track (
) Appeals sends a closing letter and copies of the Fast Track Settlement documents to the taxpayer, AC and LB&I Team Manager.
